post_info.post_title: Why do people find religion so attractive?

As a completely non-religious person, I'm not really qualified to answer, but I have a couple theories based on my observations.
 
 1. Religion provides a strong sense of community and belonging. You're part of a group with common goals and beliefs, that meets regularly, and cultivates the idea of togetherness.
 
 2. It's a security blanket. I've gone into this in detail in the past. In short, it removes the need for independent critical thought and personal responsibility. I'll likely get torched for that, but at it's base, perhaps worst level, I truly believe that's one of religion's greatest attractions. "God's mysterious ways" and "God's plan" allow people to avoid facing and taking responsibility for things they either can't, or don't want to, understand or face. 
 
 3. In much of North America, it's the norm, the "thing to do ". Chances are your parents and grandparents were religious, and it was passed on to you. Most will never question it, they'll simply maintain the status quo. It's always easier to be part of the majority, even if you don't really agree 100% or know why you're a part of it, than it is to be a part of a minority.
 
 That's a really poor and simplified explanation of my thoughts, but it's all I have time for now.

 Much of what you say is true, (although some of it seems exaggerated, we certainly have problems with refugees here in the UK and I know how easy it is to generalise and point fingers) but you cannot blame these people for the culture they have inherited.
 
 I am no advocate of the "white man's burden" in principle. But many nations are still suffering the legacy of centuries of Western colonialism and oppression, be it direct military oppression or indirect economic repression, of which the latter continues unabated to this day.
 
 To address your points about 'pagan beliefs' as opposed to Christian ones, this is simply a matter of geography and history.  In terms of recorded historical facts however, 1st World nations have grown fat and rich by plundering south America, Africa and south-east Asia. Given the genocidal extent of the original colonial efforts and the slave trade, it is hardly surprising that these areas have suffered large-scale cultural destruction and have been left with a legacy of conflict and corruption. 
 
 As you are Australian (I assume from your post), the pertinent example is the Australian Aborigines. I give you a few excerpts from John Pilger's essay "The Chosen Ones":
 
 
 Dr Richard Murray, of the Kimberley Aboriginal Medical Services Council, whose patients are all Aboriginal, has studied the cause of their suffering. "By most measures of indigenous health, Australia is the last in the world. The Aboriginal people suffer from diseases we saw the last of in the Edinburgh slums in the last century, like rheumatic fever. Here, it is the highest ever reported in the world.

 
 
 (Dr Richard Murray again) "Look at housing. 90% of overcrowded households in Australia are Aboriginal, and that's from 2% of the population. What it comes fundamentally down to is a lack of political will to allocate resources. The Federal government spends about 25% less per capita on the health of Aboriginal people compared to the rest of the population."

 
 
 Woorabinda came into existence in 1927 as one of five 'controlled' reserves that were part of an Australian gulag where people were dumped, bereft of community and family ties that matter to them sometimes more than life itself. The reserve was run by a 'Chief Protector', who exercised total power over those who were sent there; he could exile and punish people, pry into their sexual lives, confiscate their belongings, conceal their savings and commit the most recalcitrant to mental asylums. 
 
 The legacy of that history, says Elizabeth Young, an Aboriginal health worker, is that "the [Woorabinda] community now has no sense of itself and is slowly suiciding. Why? A lot of our schoolkids have dreams, but as they grow older and start rebelling, they realise, they know, they've got no future, so they do exactly what their parents did before them; they begin to waste away...In the last couple of weeks here in Woorabinda, we've had a 13 year old and a 15 year old attempt suicide. No-one's surprised."

 
 
 In white Australia, an enduring myth is the 'missing millions' of dollars that the Federal and state governments 'pour' into 'Aboriginal welfare'. It is the stuff of political and bar-room received wisdom, the fuel of bigotry, and it is false. Dr Murray in Kimberley had been referring to a nationwide health review, which disclosed, in 1997, that Aboriginal health care received considerably less funding per head of population than health care for whites: For every dollar spent per head under the national Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, only 20 cents were spent per head on Aboriginal people.
 
 I asked [Dr Murray] why the myth had such stamina. "It's part of the Australian psyche at some level. By believing that money has been spent and wasted, people move to the conclusion that conforms with what is in the back of their minds: that the real reason is innate or genetic. More important, it allows white Australians to say that it isn't their fault, it's the fault of Aboriginal people. A whole language of denigration backs this up - 'They don't look after their kids, if only they would wash themselves' - and allows the majority population to distance themselves from the truth that our First Nation continues to be denied essential citizenship rights: basic services, housing, a decent access to education, a future. 
 
 "That's why we're last in the world, particularly when compared to NZ, Canada and the US, which have comparable indigenous populations and where there has been significant progress in the last generation. In those countries, [indigenous life expectancy] is only 3-6 years less than the rest of the population. Here, the difference is 18-20 years. The question is, what makes us different?"

 
 
 When John Howard came to office in 1996, his very first act was to cut $A400 million from the Aborigines affairs budget - which he contemptuously referred to as the 'Aboriginal industry'.'Political correctness', as the new PM put it, 'has gone too far'. There should be a 'new spirit of freedom of expression'. Few doubted the real meaning of his words. He was speaking in Queensland, a state whose historic racism had, in the late nineties, demonstrated its resilience by electing to Federal Parliament Pauline Hanson as an independent candidate, on an anti-immigration, anti-Aboriginal platform...Hanson said that Aborigines were 'privileged' and that 'millions' were spent on them. She maintained, in a book written for her, that they "killed and ate their women and children and occasionally their men".

 
 There's more, about how Howard reversed the 1993 Native Title act, which "removed from common law the fiction that Australia was uninhabited when Cook landed in 1770", and passed the 1998 Native Title Amendment act which creates the potential for "42% of Australia passing from leasehold to freehold land controlled by fewer than 20,000 people..."
 
 And more, about how property laws have been passed in effect backdated decades and more, so that Aborigines, in order to keep their land, have to prove their 'continuous prescence' on land of which they have been retrospectively dispossessed. 
 
 And more, about eugenics programs, mass relocation, the 'stolen generation', what the Australian Human Rights commission called "genocide...which is the attempt to destroy a people, a culture". Bringing them home, the commission's 1997 report, called for an official apology on behalf of all Australians. John Howard refused, as he refused to recognise that the Australian National Memorial in Canberra recognise the 20,000+ Aborigines killed in frontier conflict.
